definitions.definition: to bend or turn something into a particular shape

examples.text: Twist the wire to form a circle.
Her hair was twisted into a knot on top of her head.

definitions.definition: to bend or turn something into a shape or position that is not normal or natural; to be bent or turned in this way

examples.text: He grabbed me and twisted my arm behind my back.
Her face twisted in anger.
Her mouth was twisted out of shape by grief.
His mouth twisted bitterly.
My stomach twisted into knots.
Nicola's face twisted into a grimace of disgust.
The bike was just a heap of twisted metal.
The boy's leg was twisted back painfully.

definitions.definition: to turn part of your body around while the rest stays still

examples.text: He twisted his head around to look at her.
She twisted in her chair when I called her name.
Hold your arms out to the sides and twist your upper body.
He twisted sideways to face her.
Tim twisted round and glared at her.

definitions.definition: to turn your body with quick, sharp movements and change direction often

examples.text: I **twisted and turned** to avoid being caught.
She tried unsuccessfully to twist free.
He managed to twist himself round in the restricted space.
She fired again and saw the creature twist violently.
Rachel twisted and turned in her sleep.
The prisoner twisted in his seat, trying to free the ropes around his wrists.

definitions.definition: to turn something around in a circle with your hand

examples.text: Twist the knob to the left to open the door.
Nervously I twisted the ring on my finger.
She placed her hand on the doorknob and twisted slowly.
Try twisting the handle to the right.

definitions.definition: to bend and change direction often

examples.text: The road **twists and turns** along the coast.
narrow twisting streets
a twisting staircase

definitions.definition: to injure part of your body, especially your ankle, wrist or knee, bending it in an uncomfortable way

examples.text: She fell and twisted her ankle.

definitions.definition: to wind something around or through an object

examples.text: She twisted a scarf around her head.
I twisted the bandage around his leg.
The telephone cable has **got twisted** *(= wound around itself)*.

definitions.definition: to move or grow by winding around something

examples.text: A snake was twisting around his arm.

definitions.definition: to deliberately change the meaning of what somebody has said, or to present facts in a particular way, in order to benefit yourself or harm somebody else

examples.text: You always twist everything I say.
The newspaper was accused of twisting the facts.

definitions.definition: to turn or wind strings, etc. together to make something longer or thicker

examples.text: They had twisted the sheets into a rope and escaped by climbing down it.

definitions.definition: to say or do something unkind deliberately; to make somebody who is unhappy feel even more unhappy

examples.text: Marcia laughed as she twisted the knife still deeper.
Just to twist the knife, the filmmakers have provided a surprise ending.

definitions.definition: to persuade or force somebody to do something
to persuade somebody to do anything that you want

examples.text: She has always been able to twist her parents around her little finger.

wordOrigin: Old English (as a noun), of Germanic origin; probably from the base of twin and twine. Current verb senses date from late Middle English.
